headline: Vegan Split Pea Soup
description: This vegetarian split pea soup recipe is made with barley, carrot, celery, and potato cooked with garlic, basil, and thyme for a healthy vegan soup.
name: Vegan Split Pea Soup

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Sauté onion, garlic, and bay leaf in hot oil until onions are translucent, about 5 minutes. Add water, peas, barley, and salt; bring to a boil. Reduce heat to low and simmer for 2 hours, stirring occasionally.
Add potatoes, carrots, celery, parsley, basil, thyme, and pepper. Simmer until peas and vegetables are tender, about 1 hour.

review.reviewBody: made this today and it was great. I ended up using 9 cups of water but everything else was as stated in receipt. It took a little less than 3 hours of cooking time for completion. What I also did was split the soup in half and added leftover ham into one since I eat meat but the others in my house hold do not. great reciept and I will make this again as a vegan dish as well as the addition of the ham!

I’ve made this at least three times now and will continue to make it for years to come! I pretty much followed the recipe as written although I don’t measure the spices. The only addition I made was to add a couple shakes of smoked paprika and extra water. Fantastic recipe!

I've been searching for the perfect vegetarian split pea soup recipe and this one is it! It has the classic split pea soup taste I was looking for. 
I made the following small adjustments: Used a slow cooker as another reviewer suggested, left out the barley (I needed it to be gluten free), used 10 cups of water to which I added Better Than Bullion No Chicken Base, left out the added salt, added 1/2 teaspoon smoked paprika.

I added an extra cup of water based on reviews and kept the pot covered during simmering. It was not unusually thick for a split pea soup. I also added a teaspoon of paprika because I love the smoky flavor with split peas. A delicious, hearty, pleasing soup.

This is a very yummy and hearty soup. Easy, but not a quick one. I did add 4 extra cups of water to thin it, but just adjust for your preference - thick or thin. Check your peas during the simmer. Mine did soften up in less time. Didn't miss the meat one bit.

Been using this recipe for years! I use 2 tablespoons chopped dried onion, 2 tsp dried minced garlic, 1 tsp dried parsley .......rest of ingredients are the same throw in crockpot on high 4 hours! So easy and hearty! It never fails me using all dried ingredients but if i have fresh on hand I’ll use it
Delicious! I didn’t have any barley so I added sweet potatoes.
I used half the celery because, I am not a big fan. It was wonderful!! My neighbor who is a bit picky loved it too. Freezes well also.

I did the crockpot variation but after 3-4 hours on high, the peas were still hard so I saw on another recipe for their crockpot variation to put it on low for 7-8 hours so I put mine on low for a few more hours and it was delicious

Simply amazing! I did make a few minor adjustments to the original recipe. I made it with the 5 serving adjustment and used Better Than Bouillon No Chicken Base for in the water. I doubled the garlic, used 2 medium red potatoes and all of the herbs were fresh. I put a lid on the pot during the whole 3-hour process even though it doesn't say to do so. Split Pea Soup is SUPPOSED to be thick, but I could tell at the 2-hour mark that it was going to be way too thick, so when adding the potatoes I added a two more cups of the water/bouillon mix. It came out perfectly thick yet still a soup. It's garnished with crushed pita chips and chives, and this is easily something I could eat every week....SO delicious!

I love this recipe and have made this soup many times. I'm always on the lookout for good vegan recipes, and this is one of my favorites. This is a hearty soup, especially when partially pureed. The soup freezes very well. The only change I make is too double the herbs for flavors. This recipe is definitely a thumbs up and I'm only sorry I forget to take a photo every time I make it. For people who like ham in their pea soup but want to keep the recipe vegan, I add 1/2 tsp liquid smoke.

Wonderful split pea soup. I make it exactly as described except the following:
I soak the peas in 2 and 1/2 cups of water for an hour - this allows the peas to soften better. I omit the potatoes - not needed if you want to lower the starch. I don’t miss 5hem at all.

I switched this up a little. Left out the barley, chopped all veggies up, and put in a crockpot. For the water, I used 1 32 oz box of Non-Chicken vegan broth and added about 1 1/2 c more water. In addition to the garlic, I added a tsp of garlic powder. Turned out super yummy

I liked this as a base recipe that needed a little modification. We added a few more spices and an extra 2 cups of water and I didn’t think to precook the carrots and potatoes first so the cooking time took a lot longer. Next time I’m going to try using our crock pot.

This has to be the best vegan split pea soup I have ever made. It was so good I pigged out and ate 4 large bowels of it. I did leave out the celery since I do not like it but other than that it was great and actually easy to make.
Added vegan baco bits, sprinkled at serving time
Split Pea soup is one of my favorites. I had to double the water and all spices to my taste with the exception of salt. Other than that, a great recipe.
I followed the recipe exactly and it was perfect!! I love that it has barley in it. Thanks for sharing this great recipe!

I like how easy and healthy this is. And it should be very adaptable. (I didn’t have barley so I substituted a brown/wild rice blend.) I wonder though, about putting the herbs in for an hour of simmering. Wouldn’t that destroy a lot of the herbs flavor? I don’t know, but this tasted great!

I made this soup exactly as directed and it was delicious!
Since most of my family is vegan, this was perfect for everyone to enjoy. Thank you for the recipe ;)
Great!. I did presoak and drain before cooking and I dont use oil and add a bit more carrots, celery. Yummy hearty soup.
So I did not have everything on hand. Omitted celery, and bay leaf. Added juice of a lemon to brighten it a little and grated the peel. Also a bit of red pepper flakes. Gave it some nice depth.
Put everything in a crock pot with chicken stock. Yummy.

A fabulously flavorful and hearty soup that even my non-vegan spouse loved. We served it with build-your-own veggie wrap sandwiches. The only change I made was to use vegetarian broth instead of water. Definitely a keeper!

I used 12 cups of veggie broth instead of water. Other than that it was perfect. I don’t understand all these people modifying this VEGAN recipe with chicken broth and ham bones! Sure, you can make yours that way but why using a VEGAN recipe? Go get one of those other recipes.
Excellent flavor. Followed the recipe with an additional two cups of water.
Very tasty soup. Since the other reviewers said it didn't have enough water, I started with 10 C water. By the end I had 12 C total water. Will definitely make it again

I used this recipe as a base. I made it in the crock pot and used vegetable broth instead of water and added an additional 1-2 cups of broth. Threw everything into the pot and tripled the seasonings except the salt. I also threw in a couple of dashes of Liquid Smoke.

I have been using this recipe for many years, and I can't say enough good things about it. I am not vegan, but my daughter is, and I don't eat ham anyway. This is a nice, quick, tasty recipe and the flavor surpasses that of the ham based soup I grew up with. I make this at least a few times a year. Sometimes more in the winter. It's comfort food for a snowy day.
I love this recipe!!
Really good. I threw everything in the crockpot for 10 hours on low and used a high speed blender to blend 3-4 cups at the end. I omitted the barley.
Love it. We replaced the water with vegetable broth and cook it in our pressure cooker. My wife loves it and it has become a staple for lunch. Just fabulous.

Followed the recommendations and added 4 extra cups of water. The soup was very tasty and I will make this recipe again. Next time I'll try replacing a few cups of water with vegetable stock for extra flavour.
It’s very thick so I added water. It freezes beautifully in serving size containers.
yummy
This soup is outstanding! My family loved it! It definitely needs at least 4 extra cups of liquid though. I also added more salt and less parsley. I will make this again for sure!

I read the reviews & followed advice: sautéed all the vegetables together, added additional water & even a couple of drops of liquid smoke. I did NOT add the potatoes because I didn’t have any — plus, I don’t eat potatoes. Regardless, the soup was OUTSTANDING!!! Simple, but very flavorful. Yes, it made a lot. I froze about 1/3 of it & I gave some to a friend who couldn’t believe that it was meatless. I will definitely make this again! 5 star, 2 thumbs up recipe!!
i changed a few things but it is a fairly easy recipe that works quite well
Delicious!

The instructions for this recipe were off. I had to keep adding water to keep it from burning, and the vegetables weren't cooked through at the end. I recommend adding all the vegetables in the beginning, increasing the water to 9 cups, and reducing the cooking time by 45 min.
I made this soup and it was gone in a day! I did add extra liquid. Other than that I followed the recipe as is. It was delicious! Made it again today!

Needed a gluten free veggie soup and this got rave reviews. I put everything in the crockpot and somewhere between 6-8 hours on low it hits perfection, but don’t be afraid to let it keep cooking on low. I did use organic veggie broth and exchanged the basil for more thyme. Don’t make this without the thyme!
Great!
So delicious and filling! Happy house when this is made.
My favorite split pea soup!

This was amazing! My first attempt making split pea soup and it was so great, I have no reason to ever try another recipe.

I love how thick this soup is. And the barley adds such a wonderful texture. I used to eat a lot of processed pre-packaged foods and split pea soup was one of my favourites. It's something I have definitely missed over the years. Now that I know how easy it is to make, I think it's going to become a staple! And it's so much more delicious - and nutritious - this way!

I made some tweaks to this recipe, so I thought I would share: I omitted the potatoes and celery. I added 1/4 cup extra barley - because I love barley! I also doubled the garlic, doubled the basil, and used 2 tablespoons of dried parsley in place of the 1/2 cup fresh because I didn't have any fresh on hand.

I noticed, like many others, that I did need to add extra water throughout the cooking time. I just added as needed. The 3 hours total time got the peas to that perfect soft consistency. I'm so in love with this soup :)
What a wonderfully thick vegan split pea soup recipe! I didn't have potatoes and it still turned out amazing. Even my meat loving hubby liked it. Thanks for sharing.
I read the reviews and Used 4 extra Cups Of water As Well as simmered it another hour. The flavor was very rich. I have made it 3 times now. It tastes better with chicken broth than water.

Delicious soup, and simple to make! I omitted the barley, took it easy on the parsley and used one and a half chicken bouillon cubes. Plus, a dash of sea salt. I'll use the barley next time, although soup was thick enough without it. I highly suggest trying it!
My family all loved this soup. I accidentally used lentils instead of peas. I used twelve cups of water and just about doubled the spices. It was perfect! Hubby said it was the best soup I ever made.

AWESOME recipe! My husband and children all made faces and sighed when I told them what I was making for dinner. I was worried when I realized how much of this it made and assumed I would be freezing it all for lunches for myself. Well...the ENTIRE pot was eaten by every one of them in just a day and a half! It was so good that my husband has requested I make this again today. And make a double batch. As well as keep it in the weekly rotation. I followed the recipe verbatim except adding more cups of broth and water. Loved it!
I didn’t add any barley or celery. The soup still came out fantastic. Wonderful combination of herbs.
It was excellent. The consistency and flavor was perfect. I did use half chicken broth so it is not Vegan anymore, but when I make it again I will use water only..

I made this with what I had on hand and with what I like. I used yellow split peas, onion, garlic, salt, pepper, Italian seasoning, and a tablespoon of butter. I did the quick soak method after sorting my beans, simmering them with the onion and garlic to infuse more flavor (since I didn't have veggie stock to use). After waiting an hour for the quick soak, I simmered for about 90 mins, blended it in batches in my blender, and added the butter to finish. Delicious.
Can I use bulgar instead of barley and how would I cook that?

I am just stunned at those negative reviews, the recipe said it was thick and could be made thinner with more water. So anyone complaining of that part didn't read all the directions. As far as bland is concerned, again you can always season to taste so if you use what they ask and want to add more. 
This soup smelled wonderful as it cooked yesterday morning I was making it for Lent since it has no meat in it. I like the ham hocks in split pea soup but with the potatoes and barley it wasn't lacking in texture at all. I think I added more thyme then was on the original recipe, I had soup for breakfast. Awesome!
I did not make changes and I am making it again this afternoon.

I made it again tonight. We liked the flavor, but it is an understatement to say "thick". The first time I ever had a dry soup. It dried out immediately on contact with air. I had the same experience another reviewer had, stuff stuck to the bottom and then formed a crust on the bottom of my pan which I'm currently trying to boil off! I had added a cup of chicken broth with the vegies, and I'd probably cut the potato to one. I don't think I'll make this one again.

I only changed one thing. I used Veggie stock instead of water. WOW this is such an amazing soup. My toddler loves canned pea soup, so I tried this recipe in an effort to give her some quality nutrition (so hard with a toddler sometimes). This soup is so hearty and filling. The whole family loved it. I will be making this many more times.

Made it just as written. It was fantastic. Hubby says he likes it better than any other pea soup he's ever had (and he's a carnivore). If you're making it, try it VEGAN instead of adding ham. That's the point. Promise, you'll like it just as well, and you'll have saved the life of a very grateful piggy.

Sorry this soup has potential but it needs way way more water. The soup was too thick and burned too easy. I stirred it often but it didn't matter cause a soup that thick on the burner for 4 hours is almost impossible not to burn unless you are constantly stirring for 4 hours straight. A lot of work and ingredients involved in making a soup that ended up burnt to and was unbearable to eat. Very embarrassed cooking this mess for my family.
Loved this hearty full-flavored soup! I omitted the oil, added vegetable broth to thin it. Who needs ham when there is so much flavor without it.
Great flavor but needs a little tinkering. Had to use 10 1/2 cups water total, because ingredients were burning even with 8 cups to start.
Very nice thick soup. I added roasted paprika and a dash of hot red pepper sauce for some zing. Pureed the peas and half of the veggies. Yummy

This soup is thick and hearty thanks to the barley. During the cooking process I added water, when I noticed that the water had evaporated with the simmer. It had a great flavor and thick, rich texture.

Just like the pea soup I grew up with! I followed the direction to a Tee and it turned out perfectly. It's a rich, pea flavoured soup. Got 6 lunch meals out of this one batch.
No variations needed.

This recipe tastes amazing.

Full disclosure, a few things I changed: only 1 tsp of salt (kosher sea salt); more garlic, carrots, celery, and potato, but no parsley; brown rice instead of barley. (Personal preferences and/or adapting to what I happened to have in the house.)

Most importantly, I did not need to cook it nearly as long as the recipe says – more like 1 – 1 ½ hours for the first simmer, and maybe only 30 minutes more after adding all the veg. I also used more water, somewhere between 8 and 9 cups, and I actually think I could have used even more. The soup came out very thick, and towards the end I really had to be attentive that it didn’t burn to the bottom of the pot. However, overall this recipe is super easy, low-maintenance to cook, and DELICIOUS!

This is my 11 year old son's favorite split pea soup. The rest of the family likes it too. I always replace the water with veg broth and add a splash of liquid smoke at the end. My go to for more than 5 years.

I’ve made this a few times and everyone always loves it! I’ve figured out a few tweaks that work for me: add two extra cups of water. Cook on a low heat in a heavy soup pot so that it doesn’t burn. Use fresh parsley. Perfect!

I didn't make any changes except to add more water and we cooked it in the crock pot. In adding the water I guess I should have added more salt because it was fairly bland. My timing in the crock pot must have been off because the barley stuck to the bottom of the pot. My family wasn't a big lover of split peas to begin with so I doubt we will make this again.
Excellent! The combination of split peas, potatoes and barley works well. I love this soup, and it's my kids' favorite.

I made 10 servings & made a few changes:
Omitted parsley 
Added lemon pepper 1/2 tsp 
Added 3/4 tspn of black pepper
Added smoked paprika 
Added 2 tbsp balsamic vinegar 
Added 1-1/2 cups water for 10 servings
Added potatoes after 2 hours, but waited another 20 minutes to add carrots & celery, as I like a little crunch to vary texture of soup. 
Added additional tspn of salt
This was a fantastic recipe. 
This was enough to feed 5 hungry men, with only a small bowl left over. 
The barley was a great touch. 
Will definitely be making it again, soon.

made it in the crock pot. I used veggie broth instead of water. also added a few drops of liquid smoke. didn't pre cook anything just threw everything raw/dry into crock pot. subbed quinoa/orzo for barley. didn't have issue with soup drying out..started with half the amount of liquid and added the second half toward the end..maybe that made a difference? anyway the finished product was very thick more of a stew. very tasty:)
I have made this so many times. I make it just as said, but add a little vegetable bouillon. We love it, and feel so good when eating it. Healthy healthy healthy:)
I have made this so many times. I make it just as said, but add a little vegetable bouillon. We love it, and feel so good when eating it. Healthy healthy healthy:)
This soup was so delicious. I ate it with a whole wheat roll. This recipe is a keeper!!

I usually omit the potatoes because it becomes a little too starchy with the barley. Definitely needs at least 10 c of water. Sometimes I put in a few cups of vegetable broth. Once it is all done I puree it to give it a smooth texture.
Yes, I made it. Very delicious, and I have a picky family. Very easy to make. House smells great.
this soup is awesome! i added almost double the water though. very easy and comforting.
I soaked the split peas before I started the recipe as another reviewer suggested and I substituted 3 c of vegetable stock for 3 c of water.

i made it almost exactly as the recipes but did not use, barley or parsley and added 1/2 c brown rice, and 1/2 c broccoli but the recipe is really delicious in its original form, the spices are perfect in the original recipe and loved the potatoes in it/ the original recipe tastes better than my variation/i didn't use parsley or barley/ i tasted the original recipe before i put the brown rice, and broccoli in and liked the taste more of the origianl recipe. this is probably the best split peas soup recipe i've ever tasted.

This was thick and delicious - a perfect soup for cold winter nights. Even though I cooked it for four hours, the peas were still a little hard; next time I'd cook them for five hours. I'd also leave out the potatoes - they were bland and didn't add anything to the soup. I did, though, add a sweet potato I had lying around, and it was a great addition.

This was a very easy soup to make, and it was very hardy. DH and I both really enjoyed the soup. DH had to add a little salt to his, but overall it was a creamy, thick soup that hit the spot. We will make it again.

Followed the recipe exactly for the crockpot and this was a real winner in my house. It's wonderful, flavorful and very filling. The only thing I did differently was to add BOILING water to the vegetables. Also, after about 3 hours, I added another 6 cups of boiling water because the mixture was becoming too thick to stir. This recipe is definitely a keeper!!

This has been my go to split pea soup recipe for a couple of years. I use vegetable broth instead of water and usually end up using at least 4 cups more broth as the peas, barley and potatoes take on moisture and thicken. This soup is a winner and it's incredibly nutritious as well as delicious.

Great, easy recipe with a delicious outcome. I used a mix of vegetable broth and water...and used probably another 1.5 cups of liquid than the recipe calls for. Also, I added my veggies after about 1.5 hours instead of waiting for 2 hours because I noticed the peas had almost completely broken down (not necessarily a bad thing). Soup was done in 2 hrs. If you want your peas to have more structure, I suggest adding the veggies an hour early. I will definitely make this again. The barley is an awesome touch.
Great recipe. I used a pressure cooker and it cooked in half the time

I added a few extra cups of water, substituted 4 cups of the water for chicken broth, added broccoli and substituted the barley with bulgar. Because of the extra water, it seemed to down out some of the herbs so next time I'll add more and keep the barley.

This soup is DELICIOUS! I keep going back for more. I used 8 cups of water, one vegetable bouillon cube, and slightly less than 2 cups of split peas. I also doubled the thyme and basil and omitted the parsley. Will definitely make this soup again.
Love this one, though it does need a lot more liquid than called for.

This soup is fabulous. Thank you for such a great recipe!! I adjusted ingredients to my family's diet and made it gluten-free by substituting 1/2 cup arborio rice for the barley, 8 chopped green onions for the yellow onion, and I used less fat for sauteing. Otherwise, I used two huge red potatoes rather than russet and added 1/4 t. cayenne with the spices. I started the peas in water in a separate pot while I chopped/sauteed the vegetables because I didn't have three hours for the soup to cook. As I finished chopping/measuring items, I added them to the soup. It was completely done in two hours. Be sure to use lots of water, stir frequently, and turn heat down once the potatoes and rice soften and begin to stick to the bottom of the pan.
Good. Only took about 1 1/2 hrs. altogether.

Very yummy. I made a few adjustments. I omitted the barley (didn't have any), added one large potato, used part vegetable stock & part water, and like others suggested, I added more water. It was absolutely delicious. I will definitely make it again and include the barley.
Followed exactly and even added way more liquid or it would have burned.

Great recipe. I did have to add more water a couple times during cooking. Added vegetable base to the water to give it a little more flavor. Also used cilantro because I didn't have parsley. Very good!

I followed some of the other reviewers and made the following adjustments; omitted the barley, as I did not have any, added some chopped ham and a bone, used about 10 cups of water, simmered on the stove for a few hours, and used only one potato. I actually had some leftover parsley, which I added, it gave the soup a wonderful flavor. Very good, next time I'll use Barley and omit the ham.
Fantastic! I only had sweet potatoes, which ended up being a great substitution, raising the savory factor!

I like a quick cook soup when I'm making lunch for the week on a Sunday night. I sautéed my onions, celery and garlic together then added the potatoes, carrots, spices, barley and peas and 12 cups of water seasoned with vegan veggie cubes. Brought to a boil and summered for about an hour and 20 minutes and came out perfect! Not too thick not too thin! I did have some sticking but I didn't use a heavy pot so that was probably my downfall. The soup however was delicious!
Made this for 30 people on Good Friday luncheon, everyone was surprised it was vegan, don't need any ham or bacon, the flavor is so good! This is a keeper.
